attributes.title: Stimulating energy conservation with trending minority norms: A field experiment in student housing

q1.value: Stimulating energy conservation with trending minority norms: A field experiment in student housing

q3.value:
Past research shows that trending minority norms can be an effective way of stimulating one-time desirable behaviour (Mortensen et al., 2019), but it is still unclear if trending minority norms are also effective for repetitive behaviour, like energy conservation. 

The literature about trending minority norms also is unclear about whether trending minority norms are more effective when they are about behaviour performed by the in-group or about behaviour performed by the out-group.

This study will investigate whether energy conservation in student housing can be stimulated using trending minority norms and whether trending minority norms about the in-group or about the out-group are more effective.

q4.value:
H1: Trending minority norms showing that an increasing minority reduces energy consumption, cause a bigger reduction of energy consumption than in the control group. 
H2: Trending minority norms about the in-group are more effective in stimulating energy conservation than trending minority norms about the out-group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experiment is considered a mixed design. It is between-subjects design because participants in one of the three conditions (i.e. trending minority norm in-group, trending minority norm out-group, or no norm) are compared to participants in the other conditions. It is also a within-subjects design because energy usage is measured repeatedly (during the baseline period and the intervention period).

The design has two factors, of which trending minority norm is the first factor. Trending minority norm can have the levels 'trending minority norm' or 'no norm'. The second factor is kind of group. It has the levels 'in-group' and 'out-group'. The no norm condition is a control condition. Therefore, it does not have information that is about an in-group or out-group.

q9.value: Block randomisation is used to ensure that houses in different complexes and with different amounts of tenants per house are balanced across the three conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At the time of writing, parts of the data have been downloaded but not looked at yet. The other parts are not available yet.

question.value:
The research is conducted for a student housing corporation in Wageningen, the Netherlands. Houses that this corporation rents out, that have an electricity and gas meter for a maximum of 12 students are the initial pool (i.e. 122 houses). The houses that only use electricity are omitted from the sample, because they are incomparable to houses that use gas and electricity. This means that the sample size is 95 houses.  A house will be omitted from the sample when at least one tenant from a house suspects that the study is about trending minority norms or about in-group and out-group.

The tenants of these 95 houses are the participants in the study. They are recruited by email. At the start of the experiment, they also received a note in their mail box. By filling out the survey, they have a chance of winning a 50 euro gift card.

Study timeline:
September 2nd, 2019: Start of the project, write introduction, theoretical background and conceptual framework and methodology.
January 6th, 2020: start of baseline measurement.
January 13th, 2020: end of baseline, start of experiment
January 21st, 2020: received meter readings for one week of the experiment
January 27th, 2020: end of experiment
(Date unclear): receive meter readings for the other weeks.

q13.value: 95 houses of student housing in Wageningen, the Netherlands are in the sample for this study. A total of 546 students live in these houses. One house has a maximum of 12 tenants.

q14.value: G*Power was used to calculate the smallest measurable effect size to achieve 80% power. Repeated measures ANOVA was chosen energy usage is measured over three periods: baseline, experiment week 1 and experiment week 2. Number of groups was set on two because there are two experimental groups. Correlation between repeated measures is expected to be around 0.7 because a house that always has the heating turned on high will probably not reduce this to not using heating at all, so this correlation is expected to be quite high. G*Power indicates that a sample size of 90 is expected to give an effect size f that is around 0.10. This means that the effect size that can be measured is small (Cohen, 1977). The effect size does not change dramatically when sample size would decrease to 70. Two screenshots for these power analyses are included under 'data collection procedures'.

question.value: The manipulated variables are 'trending minority norm' and 'kind of group'. Houses receive a trending minority norm or no norm. The two trending minority norm conditions can be divided in 'trending minority norm about the in-group' and 'trending minority norm about the out-group'.

A number of variables are measured. Baseline electricity usage, baseline gas usage, electricity usage during the two weeks of the experiment and gas usage during the first and second week of the experiment are also measured. The amount of tenants per house is also measured. 
A number of other variables are measured using the survey. The first is the number of items written down in the self-description task. A self-description task is included in the survey to enhance group salience. 
Age (in years), gender and nationality are also asked for in the survey.
Environmental concern is measured in the survey using the 6-item NEP scale (Dunlap & van Liere, 2008; Hawcroft & Milfont, 2010).

The last three items from the NEP scale (i.e. “Modifying the environment for human use seldom causes serious problems.”, “There are no limits to growth for nations like the United States and Canada.”, and “Mankind was created to rule over the rest of nature.”) are reversed. The average of the six items together per respondent form the variable 'NEP'.

For environmental concern (NEP) and age, the average per house is used. If only one person from a house filled the survey in, his/her score is used.

Two repeated-measures ANOVAs will be conducted; one for electricity usage and one for gas usage. The within-subjects factor name will be ‘time’ and it has three levels. This is because electricity and gas usage will be measured over three periods, namely the baseline, experiment week 1 and experiment week 2. For the first repeated-measures ANOVA, the within-factors variables are baseline electricity usage, week 1 electricity usage, and week 2 electricity usage. The ‘norm’ variable (a dummy variable coded 1 for trending minority norm in-group; 2 for trending minority norm out-group; and 3 for no norm) is added as a between-factors variable. The average scores for environmental concern, and age will be added as covariates. A very similar repeated-measures ANOVA will be conducted with the baseline gas usage, experiment week 1 gas usage, and experiment week 2 gas usage.

To test the first hypothesis, the trending minority norm in-group condition and the trending minority norm out-group condition are compared to the control group. To test the second hypothesis, the trending minority norm in-group condition is compared to the trending minority norm out-group condition.

q21.value:
The p < .05 criteria is used for significance testing. This is a two-tailed test.

There is no correction for testing multiple hypotheses and comparing multiple conditions. Only two hypotheses will be tested and three conditions are compared.

q22.value:
When at least one participant in a house suspects that the study is about trending norms or in-group and out-group, this house will also be deleted. This is because too much knowledge about the aim of the experiment can cause a bias (Boeije, ‘t Hart, & Hox, 2009).

When a participant in the survey fails to answer the manipulation check correctly, they are redirected to the end of the survey.

q23.value: If nobody from a house filled in the survey, the average from all respondents who did fill in the survey is used.

q24.value: Environmental concern may have a moderating effect on energy usage. This analysis is of explorative nature.

q25.value:
References used in this pre-registration:
Boeije, H., ‘t Hart, H., & Hox, J. (2009). Onderzoeksmethoden (8th ed.). The Hague, Netherlands: BoomLemma.

Cohen, J. (1977). Statistical Power Analysis for the Behavioral Sciences. London, England: Academic Press.

Dunlap, R. E., & Van Liere, K. D. (2008). The new environmental paradigm scale: From marginality to worldwide use. The Journal of Environmental Education, 40(1), 19-28.

Hawcroft, L. J., & Milfont, T. L. (2010). The use (and abuse) of the new environmental paradigm scale over the last 30 years: A meta-analysis. Journal of Environmental Psychology, 30(2), 143-158.

Mortensen, C. R., Neel, R., Cialdini, R. B., Jaeger, C. M., Jacobson, R. P., & Ringel, M. M. (2019). Trending norms: a lever for encouraging behaviors performed by the minority. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 10(2), 201-210.

attributes.title: An anticommons game with uncertainty and accountability
attributes.description: Previous research has shown that people tend to be less cooperative in an anticommons dilemma than in a commons dilemma. However, whereas a lot is known about commons dilemmas, very little is known about the factors that influence decisions in anticommons dilemmas. In the present research, we investigate – in a 3-person anticommons game - how uncertainty about the price a buyer is willing to pay for a set of valuable goods (WTP) influence the prices that sellers are willing to accept for them (WTA). To investigate this, we will use an experimental anticommons paradigm developed by Glockner et al.(2015), and manipulate uncertainty in 3 levels (no vs. low vs. high uncertainty). The expectation is that sellers will demand more money for their good if uncertainty is high (see De Kwaadsteniet et al., 2006). Additionally, we will investigate whether accountability (i.e., having to justify one’s decisions to the other group members) might counter this effect of uncertainty, making group members become more cooperative under accountability.

q1.value: An anticommons game with uncertainty and accountability

q3.value:
Previous research has shown that people tend to be less cooperative in an anticommons dilemma than in a commons dilemma. However, whereas a lot is known about commons dilemmas, very little is known about the factors that influence decisions in anticommons dilemmas. In the present research, we investigate – in a 3-person anticommons game - how uncertainty about the price a buyer is willing to pay for a set of valuable goods (WTP) influence the prices that sellers are willing to accept for them (WTA). To investigate this, we will use an experimental anticommons paradigm developed by Glockner et al.(2015), and manipulate uncertainty of the buyer's WTP in 3 levels (no vs. low vs. high uncertainty). The expectation is that sellers will demand more money for their good if uncertainty is high (see De Kwaadsteniet et al., 2006). Additionally, we will investigate whether accountability (i.e., having to justify one’s decisions to the other group members) might counter this effect of uncertainty, making group members become more cooperative under accountability.
The participants will be presented with a 3-person anticommons game, which is based on Glockner et al’s paradigm (2015). Our version of the game consists of three rounds that vary in the level of uncertainty about the buyer’s WTP. In each of these rounds, 3 sellers start out with a lottery ticket that they can sell to a buyer for valuable coins (each coin is worth 1 eurocent, and will be paid out in real money at the end of the experimental session). In each round the sellers have to indicate how many coins they are minimally willing to accept for their lottery ticket (WTA). If the 3 WTAs together are lower than the amount the buyer is maximally willing to pay (WTP), the three sellers will sell their lottery tickets for the amount they asked. The buyer’s WTP is randomly determined by the computer, and is either certain (i.e., 200 coins = €2), slightly uncertain (150 to 250 coins = €1.50 to €2.50), or highly uncertain (100 to 300 coins = €1 to €3). If the WTAs together exceed the buyer’s WTP, the sellers will keep their lottery tickets. With these tickets they can participate in a lottery, that is held at the end of the experimental session. Each lottery ticket has a 1 in 36 chance of yielding a prize of 20 euros. So, lottery tickets are valuable, with an expected profit of 20/36 = €0.55 per lottery ticket. In the accountability condition, participants will have to explain their decisions in the anticommons game to the other sellers, using a chat window and using player 1, 2 and 3 as the participant names (thereby keeping them anonymous).

q4.value:
Based on De Kwaadsteniet et al. (2006), we predict that:
H1: The more uncertain the WTP of the Buyer is, the higher the WTAs of the Sellers will be, (especially under no accountability). Thus, we predict a main effect of uncertainty.
Based on De Kwaadsteniet et al. (2007), we predict that:
H2. When Sellers are accountable for their decisions (as opposed to not accountable), their WTAs will be lower. So, we also predict a main effect of accountability.
H.3. The  effect of accountability is expected to be larger under uncertainty (than under certainty), and therefore we also predict an uncertainty by accountability interaction effect.
H4. We also expect an interaction effect on variance (as tested with a Levene's test; see De Kwaadsteniet et al., 2007): under certainty accountability will decrease the variance in WTAs (as Sellers will base their WTAs more on the equality rule), whereas under uncertainty accountability will not decrease the variance in WTAs.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We will use a 2(accountability: yes vs no) x 3 (uncertainty: no vs low vs high) mixed experimental design, with the latter factor as a within-subjects variable (counterbalanced).

q9.value: Groups of 3 will randomly be assigned to the conditions (accountability and order of within-subjects treatments), using a block-randomization technique programmed in oTree (using Python's itertools.cycle function)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Minimally 138 students from Leiden University will be recruited for this experiment. A group of three master students will do the recruitment by approaching students at different faculties.

q13.value: We will recruit minimally 138 students for this study, so 69 participants (= 23 groups) per between-subjects condition (no accountability vs. accountability).

q14.value: A power analysis using g*power indicates that we need minimally 134 participants to find a significant between-subjects effect of accountability, expecting a small to medium effect size of f = 0.20 (based on De Kwaadsteniet et al., 2007) and a power of 0.80. The within-subjects effects require less participants.

q15.value: We will have the lab at our disposal for three weeks. We will try to collect the 138 participants we require within that time frame, which we consider realistic.

question.value:
Accountability: Yes vs. No
Uncertainty: No vs Low vs High Uncertainty (within-subjects, counterbalanced)

Sellers' WTA will be measured in each of the 3 rounds (= maximally 300 coins)
Perceived uncertainty will be measured in each of the 3 rounds (= manipulation check, 7-point Likertscale, 1 item per round)
Felt accountability will be measured after the three rounds are finished (= manipulation check, 7-point Likert scale, 3 items)
Additionally, we will ask sex and age of the participants.

The three manipulation check questions of accountability will be combined into one measure by calculating the mean. Before calculating this mean, we will test the internal consistency of this index using Cronbach's alpha.

To test our hypotheses we will use mixed 2x3 ANOVAs:

We will test the main effects of uncertainty (to test Hypotheses 1), accountability (Hypothesis 2) and the interaction effect (to test Hypothesis 3). If we find any effects with these ANOVAs we will do post-hoc tests (i.e., Bonferroni corrected t-tests) to further interpret these effects. We will also conduct a Levene's test to test the interaction of accountability and uncertainty on variance in WTAs (to test Hypothesis 4).

The manipulation checks will also be analyzed using mixed 2x3 ANOVAs.

q20.value: To meet the homogeniety of variances assumption of ANOVA we might have to apply a square root transformation on the WTAs (e.g., De Kwaadsteniet et al., 2006), as we know from previous studies that the variance in the uncertainty conditions is often much larger than the variance in the certainty condition.

q22.value: Outliers will be included. We will use comprehension checks, but will not use these to exclude participants, just to clarify the instructions.

q23.value: If a subject does complete all three rounds of the task, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: For exploratory reasons, I will also look at the outcomes of the anticommons game in all conditions. Does uncertainty lead to lower success rates and lower group payoffs? And does accountability lead to higher success rates and higher payoffs? I can investigate this using multilevel logistic models (for the success rates) and mixed anovas for the group payoffs.

registration_responses.q12.question: Minimally 138 students from Leiden University will be recruited for this experiment. A group of three master students will do the recruitment by approaching students at different faculties.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Accountability: Yes vs. No
Uncertainty: No vs Low vs High Uncertainty (within-subjects, counterbalanced)
registration_responses.q17.question:
Sellers' WTA will be measured in each of the 3 rounds (= maximally 300 coins)
Perceived uncertainty will be measured in each of the 3 rounds (= manipulation check, 7-point Likertscale, 1 item per round)
Felt accountability will be measured after the three rounds are finished (= manipulation check, 7-point Likert scale, 3 items)
Additionally, we will ask sex and age of the participants.
registration_responses.q18.question: The three manipulation check questions of accountability will be combined into one measure by calculating the mean. Before calculating this mean, we will test the internal consistency of this index using Cronbach's alpha.
registration_responses.q19.question:
To test our hypotheses we will use mixed 2x3 ANOVAs:

We will test the main effects of uncertainty (to test Hypotheses 1), accountability (Hypothesis 2) and the interaction effect (to test Hypothesis 3). If we find any effects with these ANOVAs we will do post-hoc tests (i.e., Bonferroni corrected t-tests) to further interpret these effects. We will also conduct a Levene's test to test the interaction of accountability and uncertainty on variance in WTAs (to test Hypothesis 4).

The manipulation checks will also be analyzed using mixed 2x3 ANOVAs.

summary.value:
Piloting QUADAS-C: a survey protocol
QUADAS-C group 
Contact person: Bada Yang (b.d.yang@amsterdamumc.nl)

1. Objectives
1.	To collect users’ experiences and feedback on using QUADAS-C
2.	To assess reasons for discrepancy* within pairs of users (intra-pair discrepancy) 
3.	To assess reasons for discrepancy between pairs of users (inter-pair discrepancy)
*We define discrepancy as differences in answers between users, before a consensus meeting took place. 

2. Settings and participants
2.1. Piloting in ongoing systematic reviews
Participants will consist of review authors of ongoing diagnostic test accuracy systematic reviews (both non-comparative and comparative). Review authors will be recruited via personal networks, presentation at conferences, and via the Cochrane Editorial team. 

2.2. Face-to-face pilot meetings
We will organize two-hour face-to-face meetings in which participants will be asked to pilot QUADAS-C on comparative diagnostic test accuracy studies. We aim to recruit participants with diverse backgrounds, including healthcare providers, researchers and students. Participants will be matched in pairs so that reasons for discrepancy can be explored. We will present participants with primary studies from a range of clinical areas and study designs. Participants will generally have time to pilot only one study, but if longer meetings are possible, we will motivate participants to pilot more studies. 

3. Procedure
The study will consist of three surveys. 
1.	User Survey for objective 1 (to be completed per user)
2.	Discrepancy form A for objective 2 (to be completed by a pair of users)
3.	Discrepancy form B for objective 3 (to be completed by two pairs of users) – provided that there is sufficient time 

The study procedures are as follows.
1.	Each user pilots QUADAS-C on a study.
2.	Each user completes [User Survey]. This survey is only to be completed once per participant.
3.	A pair also completes [Discrepancy form A] together. This form is only to be completed once per pair. 
4.	Two pairs complete [Discrepancy form B] together. This form is only to be completed once per two pairs.

Each participant will be provided with the following.
(1)	The draft QUADAS-C tool
(2)	Guidance document, which contains instructions on how to use the tool. 
(3)	User Survey, Discrepancy form A, (and if there is sufficient time) Discrepancy form B.
(4)	Face-to-face pilot meetings: primary studies to pilot on (each pilot meeting may pilot a different set of studies)

4. Data collection
Piloting in ongoing systematic reviews: the survey forms will be sent by e-mail as a word document. 
Face-to-face pilot meetings: the survey forms will be filled out on paper and collected during the meeting.  

5. Data analysis
One person (BY) will track the progress of survey responses, send reminders and analyze the data. Categorical data will be summarized using percentages and qualitative data will be summarized narratively. For the primary analysis, the data of all participants will be used. As a secondary analyses, the results from categorical data will be presented separately for QUADAS-C group members and non-members.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We will test if Kanzi is more likely to be correct with round or edgy shapes.

sample.value: We will test a single subject, the bonobo Kanzi. Kanzi will receive 300 probe trials, embedded in 2700 regular trials. Based on a simulation analysis assuming a true ability of 65% correct choices we would find the intercept not overlapping with 0 in 88/100 cases (roughly, power = .88).

analyses.value:
We will use a Generalized Linear Mixed Model (GLMM) fit in a Bayesian framework using the function brm from the R package brms with default priors to analyze the data from probe trials. The model will have the following structure: 

correct ~ 1 + (1 |sound) + (1|shape_combination)

Correct: correct choice as defined above
Sound: round or edgy sounding pseudoword
Shape_combination: Unique combination of round and edgy shapes presented together in a probe trial

Inference will be based on the intercept term estimated in this model. There is a 50% chance of picking the correct picture in a probe trial. In link space, this corresponds to a value of 0. We will thus see if the 95% Credible Interval (CI) surrounding the intercept includes 0. If the estimate for the intercept is larger than 0 and its 95% CI does not include 0, we will conclude that Kanzi makes sound symbolic associations above chance.

outliers.value:
Trials exceeding the response time window (60000 ms ) — time to wait for a response to be made before trial ends — will be excluded from the analysis.

Sessions in which Kanzi does not perform above chance in regular trials will be excluded because he likely did not pay attention to the stimuli.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variable is “correct” choice during probe trials of a matching to sample task, that is a choice that reflects sound-symbolic matching. 

The task is presented on a computer screen. On a given trial, a sound cue is played after which two pictures are presented on the screen (each in one of eight potential locations, randomly selected). Probe trials are embedded within regular trials. In regular trials, Kanzi hears a familiar word (e.g. “dog”) and is shown two pictures of familiar objects (one showing a dog, the other e.g. a house). In probe trials, Kanzi hears a novel pseudoword (e.g. “bouba”) and is shown two pictures of novel abstract shapes, rather than pictures (e.g. a triangle and a circle). In each case Kanzi responds by touching one of the pictures. 

All pictures (familiar objects and shapes) are presented in greyscale. All audio stimuli (familiar english words and novel pseudowords) are recorded by the same individual. 

Correct choice is defined as follows: When hearing a “round” pseudoword, Kanzi selects the round shape, when hearing an “edgy” pseudoword, Kanzi picks the edgy shape. 

Words and shapes that will be used during probe trials have been rated on their edgy- and roundness by naive humans and have been found to elicit sound symbolic associations in humans (see Margiotoudi et al., 2019). 

Probe trials will be presented together with regular trials in blocks of 10 with 9 regular trials and 1 probe trial. To avoid having two probe trials after another, probe trials will never be the first or last trial in a block.  

In each block the combination of auditory and visual stimuli for both regular and probe trials will be unique.

Kanzi will be rewarded for every other correct choice during regular trials. On rewarded trials, correct or incorrect choice is marked by a distinct sound. Kanzi will never be rewarded on probe trials and will neither hear a positive or a negative sound following his response.

hypothesis.value:
Are great apes sensitive to sound symbolism? That is, upon hearing a “round” vs “‘sharp” sounding pseudoword, will they associate it with a round/ edgy shape? Research with human adults and children shows that they form these associations and that it may support language learning.

Previous work with great apes found no evidence for sound symbolism (Margiotoudi et al., 2019). Here we follow up on these results by testing a language trained great ape: the bonobo Kanzi. Kanzi is able to match hundreds of spoken english words to pictures that depict objects in a matching to sample task.

In the study of Margiotoudi and colleagues it was unclear whether great apes paid attention to the sound cues at all. By embedding sound symbolic probe trials in a familiar crossmodal matching to sample task, we will make sure that Kanzi is a) paying attention to the sound cue and b) is actively trying to link it to a picture.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of needle interventions for lateral elbow tendinopathy. A systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effectiveness of needle interventions for lateral elbow tendinopathy. A systematic review and meta-analysis.

q3.value: Lateral elbow tendinopathy it is one of the most common musculoskeletal disorders of the upper limb. Many interventions have been investigated for the treatment of this musculoskeletal disorder. However, there is not any systematic review of the effectiveness of needle interventions (e.g. acupuncture, electroacupuncture, dry needling) without drugs.

q4.value: Needle interventions without drugs are effective for the treatment of the lateral elbow tendinopathy

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A systematic review and meta-analysis included parallel or cross-over randomized clinical trials that used needle interventions (acupuncture, elecrtoacupuncutre, percutaneous electrical interventions or dry needling) in comparison with other group or control.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants must be al least 18 years old with lateral elbow tendinopathy diagnosed through common physical test or ultrasound imaging treated with any modalities of needle intervention without drugs (acupuncture, electroacupuncture, dry needling, percutaneous electrical interventions). Also, the included studies will be randomized clinical trials with at least one group that used a needle intervention alone or in combination with other therapy and a comparative group (other intervention or control group).

q13.value: We will analyze all studies that we caen included in the systematic review and meta-analysis

question.value: Efficacy outcomes like intensity of pain (for example numeric rating scale of pain or visual analogue scale), function/disability (for example PRTEE questionnaire or DASH questionnaire) or hand-grip strength (for example maximal voluntary contraction of hand-drip or free pain hand grip strength).

We will use Review Manager 5.3 software to statistically analyze data. If there is homogeneity between the studies we will use a fixed effect model, otherwise, a random effects model will be applied.

Heterogeneity and inconsistency will be assessed through the inspection of a forest plot, and I² test, and based on the criteria of each study.

Furthermore we will use the funnel plot to check the potential publication bias.

If we have sufficient data, we will conduct subgroup analyses according to the mean period of follow-up and needle interventions.

q25.value:
Two independent authors will screen both the titles and abstracts of the references retrieved during the searches, after which full text screening will be carried out in accordance with the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Data extraction will also be carried out by two independent authors, and data including title, author, published date, study design, and other data concerning our research questions will be collected. For all steps, any disagreements will be resolved by a third author, if required.

The risk of bias assessment will be carried out by two or more authors in accordance with the recommendations set out in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions, including following items: sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of participants, personnel and outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, selective outcome reporting, and other sources of bias. We will grade each item as “low risk”, “high risk”, or “unclear”. Disagreements will be discussed with another reviewer. Also the PEDro score was performed to evaluate the metohodological quality

attributes.title: Is attention spontaneously biased towards regularities? A direct replication and extension.
attributes.description: A pre-registered replication of Zhao, J., Al-Aidroos, N., & Turk-Browne, N. B. (2013). Attention is spontaneously biased toward regularities. Psychological science, 24(5), 667-677. By extending the number of trials, we further investigate whether the potential automatic capture of attention reported by Zhao et al. primarily occurs while the regularities are being learned, or whether it persists even after learning has occurred.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Is attention spontaneously biased towards regularities? A direct replication and extension.

sample.value: Based on Zhao et. al’s reported effect size, we calculated that we will need to collect data from 64 participants to ensure >95% power to find an effect of their reported (medium) magnitude. However, as we also intend to look at the correlation between the difference in accuracy on the 2-AFC test and the differences in RT (as explained above), we will increase the number of subjects to 84, to ensure a sufficient sample size for a Pearson correlation with an alpha of .05, 80% power, a medium effect size (p = .3) and two tails.

analyses.value:
We will first run the same analyses reported in Zhao et al. on the data from Block 1: 1) a paired-samples t-test to compare the RTs for when the visual search target is presented in the structured location vs the unstructured location 2) a one sample t-test to see if accuracy is above chance levels on the 2-AFC test.

We will then perform a paired samples t-test on the difference in RT (RT for unstructured - RT for structured location) between the two blocks, to determine whether the potential RT facilitation in Block 1 is reduced during Block 2 (in essence testing the interaction between block and condition). We will additionally perform this same test on relative RT differences (% change from Block 1 to Block 2), to ensure that potential differences do not simply reflect a training-driven proportional reduction in RTs.

Finally, we will look at whether there is a correlation between the accuracy on the 2-AFC test and the difference in RTs between the structured and unstructured locations in block 1, as well as the difference of the difference between structured/unstructured between the two blocks (i.e. do participants who show greater learning of the regularities as measured by the 2-AFC test also show a larger change in the attentional capture effect between blocks?). We will additionally use the accuracy of the reported structured location in the debrief as a between-subjects factor in an rmANOVA to test whether there are differences in the RT facilitation effect between subjects who accurately reported the location of the structured stream and those who did not.

We will report Bayes factors for all planned analyses.

outliers.value: In keeping with Zhao et. al’s analysis strategy, we will only include correct responses in the RT analysis, and exclude RTs greater than 3 standard deviations from the mean in each condition. We will additionally exclude subjects whose overall accuracy on the visual search task falls 2 standard deviations below the mean.

dependent.value:
For the exposure phase, the key dependent variable will be the response time (RT) to report the orientation of the visual search target. As in Zhao et al., we will also measure accuracy on this task, but as they reported ceiling effects we will be using this measure to exclude error trials, and like them will focus our analysis on the more sensitive RT measure.

For the surprise 2-AFC test, as in Zhao et al., the key dependent variable will be the accuracy (% correct) to report the previously seen triplet as more familiar than the novel foils.

The debriefing questions from Zhao et al. will be presented sequentially on the screen at the end of the experiment. While Zhao et al. only asked those participants who reported noticing the structure to indicate the location of the structured stream, we will have all subjects report/guess the location. The key dependent variable will be the binary accuracy of this response.

conditions.value: This is a within-subjects design - there is only one condition to which all participants will be assigned. The crucial within-participant (between-trials) factor is whether a search target appears in an unstructured versus a structured location (defined exactly as in Zhao et al.).

hypothesis.value:
1. Can we replicate Zhao, Al-Aidroos, and Turk-Browne’s (2013) Experiment 1 finding that task-irrelevant and non-salient temporal regularities automatically capture spatial attention, resulting in better performance on a visual search task presented at that location?

2. Does this potential automatic capture of attention primarily occur while the regularities are being learned, or does it persist even after learning has occurred? We will double the number of trials in the exposure phase to compare potential changes in the attentional capture effect between the first and second half of trials (Block 1 vs Block 2). The exposure phase will follow the procedure as set out in Zhao et al., with the surprise 2-AFC familiarity test presented at the end. This procedure will allow us to use Block 1 as a direct replication of Zhao et al, while extending the exposure and learning in Block 2 to investigate whether the attentional capture effect is reduced or reversed after further exposure/learning of the regularities.

This procedure will allow us to use Block 1 as a direct replication of Zhao et al, while extending the exposure and learning in Block 2 to investigate whether the attentional capture effect is reduced or reversed after further exposure/learning of the regularities.

attributes.title: Self-categorization and responses to an in-group discrimination claimer

q1.value: Self-categorization and responses to an in-group discrimination claimer

q2.value: Caitlin M. Shaw, Donna M. Garcia, nyla branscombe

q3.value: According to self-categorization theory (Turner et al., 1987), how people self-categorize can depend on the context and cues within that context. For example, contextual cues could prime a Latina woman to think about her self in terms of her ethnicity, her gender, or her individual (unique) self. Contextual shifts in self-categorization can influence how people respond to events in their environment, particularly events that are related to central group identities such as gender or ethnicity. In the proposed research, we seek to examine how self-categorization can influence an individual's responses to an ingroup member who experiences a negative outcome that s/he attributes to discrimination. We are interested in whether people induced to categorize in terms of a specific social identity (e.g., gender) rather than their unique self are more supportive of an ingroup discrimination claimer (i.e., a person who shares the social identity and blames a negative outcome on discrimination). In our study, we will induce people to think of themselves in terms of their social identity (gender in Study 1a and ethnicity in Study 1b) or individual self. Following Wang and Dovidio's (2017) procedure, participants in the social categorization condition will complete a collective self-esteem scale (related to gender in Study 1a and ethnicity in Study 1b). Those in the individual categorization condition will complete a personal self-esteem scale. In Study 1a, female participants will then read a scenario about a woman intern who gets denied a full-time position, with half the participants reading the woman labeled the rejection as discrimination and the other half reading she blamed the rejection on her personal performance during the job interview. In Study 2b, Latinx participants will read the same scenario, but about a Latino male target who blames discrimination or himself for the job failure.

q4.value:
We are measuring female (Study 1a) or Latinx (Study 1b) participants’ support for an ingroup target who blames an unfair job rejection on either discrimination or personal performance (i.e., poor interview performance).  We are measuring support in terms of a) negative affective response to target, b) positive affective response to target, c) liking for target, d) belief that target’s attribution for rejection harms the ingroup, e) agreement with target’s attribution for the rejection, f) perceptions that the target experienced discrimination, and g) perceptions that the target was harmed by the rejection. For negative affect and harms ingroup, lower scores = greater support. For all other variables, higher scores = greater support.

Based on SCT and previous research (e.g., Garcia et al., 2005; 2010), we are predicting interactions for all the above variables with support being higher when self-categorization and target attribution are congruent (i.e., self-categorization and personal performance or group-categorization and discrimination) rather than incongruent (i.e., self-categorization and discrimination or group-categorization and personal performance). We also expect that perceived discrimination and harm to target will reveal two main effects. We expect that both perceived discrimination and harm to target will be higher in discrimination than person responsibility condition and higher in group-categorization than individual condition.

In addition to the above hypotheses, we predict that the conditional effects of perceptions of the target (negative affect, positive affect, and liking) will occur indirectly through evaluations of the target’s attribution (harm to ingroup and agreement with attribution) and perceptions of the job decision (perceived discrimination). We expect that harm to ingroup will be higher in incongruent than congruent conditions, which will be associated with decreased liking and positive affect and increased negative affect. We expect that agreement with attribution and perceived discrimination will be higher in congruent than incongruent conditions, which will be associated with increased liking and positive affect and decreased negative affect.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: There is no direct interaction between the researchers and the study subjects because the study is completed fully on-line.

question.value:
This study is a 2(self-categorization: individual or group) x 2(attribution: personal
responsibility or discrimination) randomized between-subjects design. The study also includes a test of indirect effects with the effects of the interaction between attribution and self-categorization on the target evaluation outcome measures occurring through perceptions that the target experienced discrimination, was harmed by the job rejection, responded appropriated to the job decision, and the target's response was harmful for the ingroup.

q9.value: Random assignment into conditions will be determined via the randomization option in the Qualtrics survey. Participants will be randomized into the treatments at two different points. They will initially be randomized to the self-categorization condition in which they will complete questions related to individual or collective self-esteem. Afterward, they will be randomized to the attribution condition in which they read about a highly-qualified target who was denied a full-time position and either blamed the failure on personal performance or discrimination from the interviewer.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Access to the data set has been limited to the two researchers only. According to the consent form, participants were told they would only receive payment/credit if they correctly answered the memory questions after reading the target scenario. Importantly, the questions relate to the content of the scenario, not the manipulations. Furthermore, participants who failed these questions were diverted to the end of the study and were unable to answer any to dependent variable questions. One of the researchers identified and removed from the data set anyone who failed the memory questions. The researcher then granted credit or payment to those who passed and informed those who failed why they would not receive credit/payment. No analyses or visual assessment of the data have been conducted thus far.

question.value:
For Study 1a, we collected 347 women using CloudResearch, which is a crowd-sourcing research tool. For Study 1b, we recruited 302 Latinx undergraduate participants who were currently enrolled in a psychology course at CSUSB. These participants were recruited through the psychology department's SONA system at CSUSB.

CloudResearch participants received $1.75 for their 20-minute participation. SONA participants received 1 unit credit (equal to approximately 1% extra credit in a course) for their 20-minute participation. Participants who completed the survey via SONA could only access the study if they previously indicated in the SONA prescreen that they identify as Latinx. The CloudResearch site distributed the survey to individuals who previously identified as female in the CloudResearch system.

q13.value: Our target sample size was 302 participants for each study (i.e., 620 participants in total). We planned to collect data from 302 participants via SONA systems and 302 via CloudResearch site. According to G*Power, we required 256 participants for each study, but we aimed for 302 (18% inflation) in case we needed to exclude careless responders. The 18% inflation rate was based on past data collection in our lab (and consistent with published work on careless responding) showing that approximately 18% of participants carelessly respond to the outcome measures.

q14.value: We used G*Power for our power analyses, with an effect size of partial eta squared = .03 (f=.1758631), alpha set at .05, beta set at .80, numerator df = 1 and number groups = 4.

q15.value:
CloudResearch overfilled our request but did not charge us for the extra 45 participants who completed the study. 
We will use the full sample collected. in SONA, 302 participants completed the study, which was consistent with our goal.

question.value:
We manipulated two variables in the studies: the type of self-categorization and the attribution type. 

Our self-categorization manipulation followed the same procedure used by Wang and Dovidio (2017). To manipulate social categorization, we asked participants to reflect on their feelings about themselves in terms of their gender (1a) or ethnicity (1b) and complete 7 items from the Luhtanen & Crocker's (1992) Collective Self-Esteem Scale (e.g., ‘‘My gender [ethnic] identity is an important reflection of who I am’’). To manipulate individual identity, we asked participants to reflect on their feelings about themselves as unique individuals and rate their agreement with 7 items taken from the Rosenberg (1965) Self-Esteem Scale (e.g., ‘‘I feel that I have a number of good qualities’’). All items were rated on 7-point scales, ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Our attribution manipulation was embedded in the scenario that participants read. This scenario was about an intern at a company who applied for and was denied a full-time permanent position, despite being more highly qualified than other interns whose applications were successful. In Study 1a, all the successful interns were men and in Study 1b, they were all White. According to the scenario, the target completed an exit survey at the conclusion of the internship, which asked whether she (1a) or he (1b) received a full-time position, and to provide an explanation for that outcome. In both conditions, the target acknowledged that s/he was not offered a position. The reason s/he gave for not getting the position, however, varied by condition. In the personal performance condition, the target claimed s/he did not perform well during the job interview. In the discrimination condition, the target claimed s/he experienced gender (1a) or ethnic (1b) discrimination from the interviewer.

We are interested in examining individuals' perceptions of an intern at a company who is denied a permanent paid position. Participants will respond to questions measuring their evaluations of the target's explanation, the target's likeability, and the interviewer. We are also interested in their perceptions of why the target was rejected and their feelings about their group identity (gender in 1a and ethnicity in 1b).

We will use two approaches to analyze data. Our first approach will be to test variables in which we predict main effects or two-way interactions. Because some of these variables will not be included in our moderated serial mediation model, we will use ANOVAs in SPSS to test all outcome variables for consistency in presentation. For each of Negative Affect, Positive Affect, Liking, Perceived Harm to Group, Perceived Discrimination, Perceived Harm to Target, Appropriateness of Target's Labeling of Job Decision, we will conduct 2(self-categorization: individual or group) x 2(attribution: personal responsibility or discrimination) between-subjects ANOVAs to assess our predicted interactions between self-categorization and attribution. We will also conduct planned comparisons to disaggregate the interactions and examine simple main effects within the Attribution and Self-Categorization conditions. We will conduct the same 2 x 2 analyses for the following manipulation and story checks: Complainer, Honesty, Avoids Personal Responsibility, and Group Identification. We expect a main effect of Attribution for Honesty and Avoids Personal Responsibility, and Complainer. We expect a main effect of Self-Categorization for Group Identification. We have attached the proposed syntax.

Our second approach will be to use PROCESS Model 7 (Hayes, 2018, v3.4) to test our moderated mediation models with each of the three target evaluation outcome variables (i.e., Negative Affect, Positive Affect, and Liking) as the Y Variable. In all three model tests, Attribution will be the predictor variable (X), Perceived Discrimination, Appropriateness of Labeling, Target Harm, and Group Harm will be the mediators (M), and Self-Categorization will be the moderator variable (W). We expect that the effects of the Attribution x Self-Categorization interaction on the outcome variables will indirectly occur through the mediators. We expect the interactive effect on the mediators will be positive on the first three mediators and negative on the fourth mediator, and the effects of mediators 1-3 on the target evaluation outcomes will also be positive and mediator 4 will be negative.

q21.value: For the ANOVAs, we will be using p = or < .05. For the indirect effect tests, we will be using 95% confidence intervals with significance being indicated by the absence of 0 between the lower and upper CI.

q22.value:
We will exclude participants in the poor performance condition for who failing the attribution manipulation check if they select less than 5 on the 7-point scale for the question assessing agreement that the target attributed the job failure to poor interview performance. We will exclude participants in the discrimination condition if they select less than 5 for the question that the target attributed the failure to discrimination. Participants who select the wrong option regarding the words they typed for the Robo Check will also be excluded. Finally, we will exclude participants who incorrectly identify the gender (Study 1a) or ethnicity (Study 1b) of the interns who received job offers, the target, and the interviewer. 

As per below, we will also exclude the data from any participant who did not respond to two or more items in any of the primary measures.

q23.value: We will exclude from the sample the data from any participant who did not respond to two or more items in any of the primary measures.

q24.value: We will use the customization option in PROCESS (Hayes, 2018, v3.4) to conduct an exploratory test of possible moderated serial mediation models with each of the three target evaluation outcome variables (i.e., Negative Affect, Positive Affect, and Liking) as the Y Variable. In all three model tests, Attribution will be the predictor variable (X), Perceived Discrimination will be the first serial mediator (M) variable in the model and Group Harm, Appropriateness of Labeling, and Target Harm will be the second set of serial mediators (M), and Self-Categorization will be the moderator variable (W).

attributes.title: Self-esteem Importance, Ambivalence, Certainty - Interest in Self-esteem (Study 3)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Self-esteem Importance Ambivalence: Interest in Self-esteem Feedback Conceptual Replication

other.value: Yes: we would like the sample size to be at least approximately equal in the two experimental conditions. Therefore, if the sample size in the cash draw group is 75% or smaller the sample size of the self-esteem feedback group after the first week, we will tweak the reminder email to increase the size of the cash reward. We will do this without calculating SEI+/- in any way, so we cannot check on our main hypothesis when doing this.

sample.value: About 1900 individuals will be invited to participate. However, we cannot precisely estimate what our sample size will be because it will depend on the show-up rate. In a previous study we emailed ~1900 people and 493 people responded, so a reasonable guess would be that we would again obtain about n = 500. However, this is only a guess and the previous study was run earlier in that year’s academic year. Because we are running the present study in February, there is a good chance that less people will be interested in doing any studies, decreasing our effective sample size.

analyses.value:
We will conduct two simple t-tests, which examine whether advertising condition (cash award vs. self-esteem feedback) is associated with a difference in the average SEIS-Positive and/or SEIS-Negative scores of people who complete the study.
We hypothesize that SEIS-Positive and –Negative scores will each be higher in the self-esteem feedback condition relative to the cash award condition.
We will also attempt to control for possible differences in simple trait self-esteem when looking at this difference in a regression framework. That is,
Condition (contrast-coded) + trait self-esteem --> self-esteem importance (positive)
And
Condition (contrast-coded) + trait self-esteem --> self-esteem importance (negative)

outliers.value: We will only retain scores from participants who complete the ENTIRE survey in each given condition, since our interest is in the completion of a study for a given reward, not initial attraction.

dependent.value: The main DV is continuous scores on our two scales: the scale of self-esteem importance (positive) and the scale of self-esteem importance (negative).

conditions.value:
All possible participants will be assigned to one of two conditions, in which they are invited to participate in a study in exchange only for personality (self-esteem) feedback, OR for a cash award. They will be given two weeks to complete the survey after the invitation is sent out, to help avoid the risk that some participants may not complete the survey due to irrelevant reasons (e.g. if we ran the survey for only a couple of days, participants might simply have a few exams on those days, creating an artificial barrier against their participating). We reason that two weeks should provide an adequate time to complete the brief survey, including two weekends during which participants should hopefully be freed to respond.
Using a Qualtrics function, individuals who have not completed the survey after the first week will receive an automatic reminder from Qualtrics reminding them that they only have seven days left, and reminding them that they can get self-esteem feedback (vs cash award) by completing it.

hypothesis.value:
We will be contacting participants from a large prescreen list via email. These individuals will be invited to learn about their self-esteem by completing a very quick study, or to receive an entry into a cash draw. In reality, regardless of condition, they will indeed receive bona fide feedback about their relative self-esteem levels, reported as low/medium/high based on normative data we collected through an earlier prescreening process – and also be entered into a cash draw. Therefore, the only difference among participants is whether their invitation email focuses on getting accurate self-esteem feedback, or focuses on getting a possible cash award.
Each participant is directed to a Qualtrics survey in which they fill out a consent form, then complete the BFI-44 (a 44 item scale that takes under five minutes to complete), the Self-Esteem Importance Scale (a 20-item scale that takes about two minutes to complete), and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (a 10-item scale that takes about one minute to complete). The inclusion of the BFI is to provide some “work” for participants to do; after all, people who are highly motivated to learn about self-esteem should be willing to answer some self-esteem irrelevant items to get to the self-esteem feedback that they desire. The SEIS has been included so we can assess a roughly four-month test-retest reliability of that measure. Afterwards, participants receive genuine information feedback about their trait self-esteem based on their actual scores. That is, participants with low self-esteem (below 25th percentile) get one kind of feedback, whereas participants with high self-esteem (above 75th) get a different feedback. Those in the middle get told that their self-esteem is moderate. (See materials for specific feedback provided.)
At the end of the study, we will explain the true purpose of the study to participants in a debriefing form: all that we are interested in is who did this ‘bonus study’ whose sole reward is learning about their self-esteem (vs cash award). We hypothesize that self-esteem importance scores should be elevated in the study version that is only reinforced with accurate self-esteem feedback, compared to the study version in which cash incentives are used. The logic is that people who think that self-esteem leads to important consequences – positive or negative – should be more motivated to learn about their self-esteem levels, since knowing this information should be more consequential in their minds. However, they should not be any more interested in receiving a cash award (a very general and non-specific reinforcer).

registration_responses.name: Self-esteem Importance Ambivalence: Interest in Self-esteem Feedback Conceptual Replication
registration_responses.other: Yes: we would like the sample size to be at least approximately equal in the two experimental conditions. Therefore, if the sample size in the cash draw group is 75% or smaller the sample size of the self-esteem feedback group after the first week, we will tweak the reminder email to increase the size of the cash reward. We will do this without calculating SEI+/- in any way, so we cannot check on our main hypothesis when doing this.
registration_responses.sample: About 1900 individuals will be invited to participate. However, we cannot precisely estimate what our sample size will be because it will depend on the show-up rate. In a previous study we emailed ~1900 people and 493 people responded, so a reasonable guess would be that we would again obtain about n = 500. However, this is only a guess and the previous study was run earlier in that year’s academic year. Because we are running the present study in February, there is a good chance that less people will be interested in doing any studies, decreasing our effective sample size.
registration_responses.analyses:
We will conduct two simple t-tests, which examine whether advertising condition (cash award vs. self-esteem feedback) is associated with a difference in the average SEIS-Positive and/or SEIS-Negative scores of people who complete the study.
We hypothesize that SEIS-Positive and –Negative scores will each be higher in the self-esteem feedback condition relative to the cash award condition.
We will also attempt to control for possible differences in simple trait self-esteem when looking at this difference in a regression framework. That is,
Condition (contrast-coded) + trait self-esteem --> self-esteem importance (positive)
And
Condition (contrast-coded) + trait self-esteem --> self-esteem importance (negative)
registration_responses.outliers: We will only retain scores from participants who complete the ENTIRE survey in each given condition, since our interest is in the completion of a study for a given reward, not initial attraction.
registration_responses.dependent: The main DV is continuous scores on our two scales: the scale of self-esteem importance (positive) and the scale of self-esteem importance (negative).
registration_responses.conditions:
All possible participants will be assigned to one of two conditions, in which they are invited to participate in a study in exchange only for personality (self-esteem) feedback, OR for a cash award. They will be given two weeks to complete the survey after the invitation is sent out, to help avoid the risk that some participants may not complete the survey due to irrelevant reasons (e.g. if we ran the survey for only a couple of days, participants might simply have a few exams on those days, creating an artificial barrier against their participating). We reason that two weeks should provide an adequate time to complete the brief survey, including two weekends during which participants should hopefully be freed to respond.
Using a Qualtrics function, individuals who have not completed the survey after the first week will receive an automatic reminder from Qualtrics reminding them that they only have seven days left, and reminding them that they can get self-esteem feedback (vs cash award) by completing it.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
We will be contacting participants from a large prescreen list via email. These individuals will be invited to learn about their self-esteem by completing a very quick study, or to receive an entry into a cash draw. In reality, regardless of condition, they will indeed receive bona fide feedback about their relative self-esteem levels, reported as low/medium/high based on normative data we collected through an earlier prescreening process – and also be entered into a cash draw. Therefore, the only difference among participants is whether their invitation email focuses on getting accurate self-esteem feedback, or focuses on getting a possible cash award.
Each participant is directed to a Qualtrics survey in which they fill out a consent form, then complete the BFI-44 (a 44 item scale that takes under five minutes to complete), the Self-Esteem Importance Scale (a 20-item scale that takes about two minutes to complete), and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (a 10-item scale that takes about one minute to complete). The inclusion of the BFI is to provide some “work” for participants to do; after all, people who are highly motivated to learn about self-esteem should be willing to answer some self-esteem irrelevant items to get to the self-esteem feedback that they desire. The SEIS has been included so we can assess a roughly four-month test-retest reliability of that measure. Afterwards, participants receive genuine information feedback about their trait self-esteem based on their actual scores. That is, participants with low self-esteem (below 25th percentile) get one kind of feedback, whereas participants with high self-esteem (above 75th) get a different feedback. Those in the middle get told that their self-esteem is moderate. (See materials for specific feedback provided.)
At the end of the study, we will explain the true purpose of the study to participants in a debriefing form: all that we are interested in is who did this ‘bonus study’ whose sole reward is learning about their self-esteem (vs cash award). We hypothesize that self-esteem importance scores should be elevated in the study version that is only reinforced with accurate self-esteem feedback, compared to the study version in which cash incentives are used. The logic is that people who think that self-esteem leads to important consequences – positive or negative – should be more motivated to learn about their self-esteem levels, since knowing this information should be more consequential in their minds. However, they should not be any more interested in receiving a cash award (a very general and non-specific reinforcer).
